thread.title: Rubens proving popular, air drumming and all
thread.title_full: Rubens proving popular, air drumming and all

title: Rubens proving popular, air drumming and all
text:
The Rubens to perform at sold out Tanks Art Centre by: (L-R) The Rubens’ Will Zeglis, Elliot Margin, Zaac Margin, Sam Margin, and Scott Baldwin. Picture: BRADEN FASTIER Source: News Corp Australia 
CHART-topping Australian outfit The Rubens took a chance on their upcoming (and first) gig in Cairns. 
Band member Elliott Margin told The Cairns Post going to a new territory was “always a gamble.” 
“You don’t know if you have a fan base there at all,” he said. 
Turns out in Cairns they do. The five-piece (pictured) have sold out their Tanks Arts Centre engagement. 
The concert is part of a larger tour the band have embarked on and comes on the back of their most recent album Hoops . 
Margin said the tour had been going really well. 
“It’s been a while obviously for us off cycle. So we just did a whole bunch of writing and stuff, but no shows,” he said. 
“To be back on the road, it’s a relief because it is, you know, one of the main reasons that we do it — playing live.” 
Margin revealed people had shown their commitment to the band during the tour too. 
“By the first show, people were singing lyrics to songs that haven’t even been released as singles at all,” he said. 
“It’s like they’ve just gone and done their research.” 
The tour has already taken them to places like Western Australia, Tasmania and South Australia. 
Unsurprisingly, Margin confirmed that touring involved a lot of flying. 
Asked if there was somebody he didn’t want to sit next to when flying, Margin was diplomatically noncommittal. But he revealed guitarist Zaac might not be another passenger’s favourite, saying he could be “jittery”. 
“He’s listening to music and he’ll start drumming on the seat in front,” he said. 
“It’s going to be in time, but it’s going to be keeping you awake.”
